description: Login through google is not working. "Something get wrong" error.
Installed it yesterday and it worked just fine, now it crashes every time I try to open it.

This goes in the "works like normal" bucket for those of us who work via multi-platform desktop environments. 

Though my home of choice, the 'nix world is has been getting some rock solid, first-rate desktop applications of the quality I've come to expect from those packaged for consumer OS's such as Windows and MacOS. 

This app fits into the rock-solid bucket. Plus, todoist offers an API and many integrations out-of-the-box. And you can squash the sidebar? There's little here not to like. An excellent app thus far.
summary: A stable and high-quality Linux desktop application

description: I like Todoist itself a lot. This app is no different from the website really, only in desktop app form. Stable and fast.

summary: Pleased to find a fully supported app for Linux

description: Just perfect! Thanks for this!

I tend to be very disorganized, having Aspergers and all, and found that the Todoist workflow has many features that are helpful, including syncing to mobile devices and calendar integrations. I got this app years before I switched to Linux, and it's nice to know it works almost identically here.

Yes, it is a paid subscription service for $50 per year, and yes, it's proprietary. If those two things are turn-offs for you, look elsewhere.

This being said, Todoist has some features such as projects and reminders, and can even set reminders based on location (only on mobile clients).

Perhaps the best part of this is that adding events takes advantage of natural language processing. Typing due dates like "Friday," "Tomorrow," or "Weekly" will automatically set the due date, and remove the recognized text from the event name. You can also add to projects using #[project] and add a tag using @[tag]. 

Unfortunately, there are some problems with the Linux client in particular. Todoist can't be set to launch at the start of a session, meaning I have to write a script to open it on login, which means I also have to close the window it opens. Again, absolutely not a huge issue, but might be how it talks to KDE. Speaking of KDE, Todoist has no plasmoids that could display your to-do list on the desktop. 
On Windows, Todoist adds a keystroke (I think its Win+Shift+Q) that summons a pop-up to add an event from anywhere. This doesn't happen on Linux, which is annoying. I would really give kudos if the Doist Devs could add this feature through the DE's shortcut system.

This is a great app for anyone out there, and has saved me several times 2 years into college now.
summary: Very Useful Application with some client-side flaws
